qas.question: What type of decoration was often seen in tombs?
What could be used to prevent a door from closing in a place of burial?
What was the afterlife of the immortals called during this period?
What is the commonly held notion regarding the dual nature of the soul called?
What function did the holes in the top and bottom of the tomb tiles enable them to do?

context: Families throughout Han China made ritual sacrifices of animals and food to deities, spirits, and ancestors at temples and shrines, in the belief that these items could be utilized by those in the spiritual realm. It was thought that each person had a <a3_0>two-part soul<a3_0/>: the spirit-soul (hun 魂) which journeyed to the afterlife paradise of immortals (<a2_0>xian<a2_0/>), and the body-soul (po 魄) which remained in its grave or tomb on earth and was only reunited with the spirit-soul through a ritual ceremony. These tombs were commonly adorned with uniquely decorated <a0_0><a1_0>hollow clay tiles<a1_0/><a0_0/> that function also as a doorjamb to the tomb. Otherwise known as tomb tiles, these artifacts feature holes in the top and bottom of the tile <a4_0>allowing it to pivot<a4_0/>. Similar tiles have been found in the Chengdu area of Sichuan province in south-central China.
